p: Since the first Genome-Wide Association Study on sporadic Parkinson's disease was performed in 2005, a new era starts to gain attention in the genetic basis of Parkinson's disease [ 14]. Advances in genotyping technology and meta-analysis have allowed researchers to rapidly identify common variants related to PD in different populations [ 4]. Though some of the previously nominated PD risk genes were firstly reported in familiar Parkinson's disease (such as SNCA and LRRK2), both of them were successfully replicated in unrelated sporadic PD patients [ 15]. Additional associated studies and subsequent meta-analysis contributed a lot to identifying the unnoticed variants that can also drive PD risk, ITGA8 as an example [ 8].
